content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!-- generator="Joomla! - Open Source Content Management" --> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"  xml:lang="en-gb">  <title type="text">National Collaborative for Women's History Sites</title>  <subtitle type="text">National Collaborative for Women's History Sites</subtitle>  <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://ncwhs.org"/>  <id>http://ncwhs.org/index.php</id>  <updated>2015-03-19T13:50:26-04:00</updated>  <generator uri="http://joomla.org" version="2.5">Joomla! - Open Source Content Management</generator>  <link rel="self" type="application/atom+xml" href="http://ncwhs.org/index.php?format=feed&type=atom"/>  <entry>   <title>Welcome</title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://ncwhs.org/index.php/154-uncategorised/199-welcome"/>   <published>2012-11-10T00:50:18-05:00</published>   <updated>2012-11-10T00:50:18-05:00</updated>   <id>http://ncwhs.org/index.php/154-uncategorised/199-welcome</id>   <author>    <name>Michael Regoli</name>    <email>ncwhs@regoli.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><span style="font-size: medium;">The National Collaborative for Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Sites (NCWHS) supports and promotes the preservation and interpretation of sites and locales that bear witness to women's participation in American life. The Collaborative makes women's contributions to history visible so that all women's experiences and potential are fully valued. Support our efforts by becoming a member. <a href="index.php/membership">Learn more &gt;</a></span></p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><span style="font-size: medium;">The National Collaborative for Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Sites (NCWHS) supports and promotes the preservation and interpretation of sites and locales that bear witness to women's participation in American life. The Collaborative makes women's contributions to history visible so that all women's experiences and potential are fully valued. Support our efforts by becoming a member. <a href="index.php/membership">Learn more &gt;</a></span></p></div></content>   <category term="Featured" />   <category term="Uncategorised" />  </entry>  <entry>   <title>NCWHS March 2015 News - Women's History Month Edition </title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://ncwhs.org/index.php/136-news/272-ncwhs-march-2015-news-women-s-history-month-edition"/>   <published>2015-03-02T16:16:23-05:00</published>   <updated>2015-03-02T16:16:23-05:00</updated>   <id>http://ncwhs.org/index.php/136-news/272-ncwhs-march-2015-news-women-s-history-month-edition</id>   <author>    <name>Marla Miller</name>    <email>mmiller@history.umass.edu</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><strong>Dear Friends -</strong><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdHaving just returned from India, I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm more aware than ever that women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history truly is everywhere. In addition to visiting the home of Indira Ghandi (which is a museum and memorial to her, marking the location of her \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdmartyrdom\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd), I also had the pleasure of meeting with the Woman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Christian Temperance Union of India and visiting their historic headquarters in Delhi. Though the building is in need of repair, it\ufffd\ufffd</span><img src="https://gallery.mailchimp.com/e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9/images/a69e9844-551c-4900-a405-f3da535a6c2b.jpg" border="0" width="200" height="150" align="right" /><span>has served as their home since it was opened in 1934. The World\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds WCTU was founded by Frances Willard in 1889 and was one of the earliest international organizations for women. The India WCTU was founded not long after in 1893. Originally composed of British and American women, most of whom were connected to Christian missionary work in India, it slowly transformed itself into an organization of Indian Christian women and remains this today. It was a fascinating visit, to not only a most historic women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history site, but a reminder that the need for preserving women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history is a global need.</span><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdNow for NCWHS news. We have just completed our first ever annual appeal and are very pleased with the successful result. To this date, we have raised $3,455 toward our $4,000 goal. In order to raise the remaining funds, we are conducting a\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>membership drive</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdduring the month of March in honor of women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history month. If you are not a current member of NCWHS, please consider joining. You can do this with a credit card by going\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=dcc1b3d605&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">here</a><span>\ufffd\ufffdand signing up online, or with a check by\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=fa4689e0bf&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">downloading</a><span>\ufffd\ufffdthe form and mailing it in. If you are a current member and know of someone who would appreciate a gift membership, please consider that. For gift memberships, we cannot (yet) accept online payments, so please use the\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=55fe8ce504&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">paper form</a><span>. We so appreciate everyone who gave to our annual appeal (and especially our challenge grant donor for spurring us on) and if you can help us reach the finish line, please do so!</span><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdNCWHS members will soon have access to two new online features that we are excited to unveil - an online member directory and members-only content. These\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>exclusive member features</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdare the result of the feedback we received from our member survey, and more will come in the future, including a member forum for exchanging ideas. So, there are more reasons than ever to join NCWHS.</span><br /><img src="https://gallery.mailchimp.com/e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9/images/abb4fa7f-93e1-4367-acd3-84cbeba1577b.jpg" border="0" width="100" height="114" align="right" /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdFor our members in the midwest, we are please to announce a\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>joint women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history month event</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdat our headquarters at the Evanston History Center in Evanston, Illinois. Author (and former NCWHS board member) Susan Ferentinos will speak about her recently published book,\ufffd\ufffd</span><em>Interpreting LGBT History at Museums and Historic Sites</em><span>, discussing the ways historians approach the study of same-sex relationships; the challenges to uncovering this past; and the efforts of museums, historic sites, and community groups to preserve this history and present it to the wider public. This program will be held on Thursday, March 26th at 7 pm (reception at 6:30) and is designed not only for those connected to a museum or site, but also for anyone who is concerned with issues of inclusion and diversity in our interpretation of the past. For more information about registering for this event, which is free to NCWHS members, visit our\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=702aa62a9c&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">website</a><span>.</span><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdFinally, we know that word of mouth is our most important communication tool. Please\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>forward this newsletter</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdalong to anyone in your circle who would enjoy connecting with us. Building our network of members, supporters and friends is so important to us as an organization, and we know it is important to you, as we all work together to give women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history its place in American (and World) history.</span><br /><br /><strong>As always, stay in touch!</strong><br /><br /><span>Lori Osborne</span><br /><span>NCWHS Vice President</span></p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><strong>Dear Friends -</strong><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdHaving just returned from India, I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm more aware than ever that women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history truly is everywhere. In addition to visiting the home of Indira Ghandi (which is a museum and memorial to her, marking the location of her \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdmartyrdom\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd), I also had the pleasure of meeting with the Woman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Christian Temperance Union of India and visiting their historic headquarters in Delhi. Though the building is in need of repair, it\ufffd\ufffd</span><img src="https://gallery.mailchimp.com/e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9/images/a69e9844-551c-4900-a405-f3da535a6c2b.jpg" border="0" width="200" height="150" align="right" /><span>has served as their home since it was opened in 1934. The World\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds WCTU was founded by Frances Willard in 1889 and was one of the earliest international organizations for women. The India WCTU was founded not long after in 1893. Originally composed of British and American women, most of whom were connected to Christian missionary work in India, it slowly transformed itself into an organization of Indian Christian women and remains this today. It was a fascinating visit, to not only a most historic women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history site, but a reminder that the need for preserving women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history is a global need.</span><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdNow for NCWHS news. We have just completed our first ever annual appeal and are very pleased with the successful result. To this date, we have raised $3,455 toward our $4,000 goal. In order to raise the remaining funds, we are conducting a\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>membership drive</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdduring the month of March in honor of women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history month. If you are not a current member of NCWHS, please consider joining. You can do this with a credit card by going\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=dcc1b3d605&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">here</a><span>\ufffd\ufffdand signing up online, or with a check by\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=fa4689e0bf&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">downloading</a><span>\ufffd\ufffdthe form and mailing it in. If you are a current member and know of someone who would appreciate a gift membership, please consider that. For gift memberships, we cannot (yet) accept online payments, so please use the\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=55fe8ce504&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">paper form</a><span>. We so appreciate everyone who gave to our annual appeal (and especially our challenge grant donor for spurring us on) and if you can help us reach the finish line, please do so!</span><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdNCWHS members will soon have access to two new online features that we are excited to unveil - an online member directory and members-only content. These\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>exclusive member features</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdare the result of the feedback we received from our member survey, and more will come in the future, including a member forum for exchanging ideas. So, there are more reasons than ever to join NCWHS.</span><br /><img src="https://gallery.mailchimp.com/e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9/images/abb4fa7f-93e1-4367-acd3-84cbeba1577b.jpg" border="0" width="100" height="114" align="right" /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdFor our members in the midwest, we are please to announce a\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>joint women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history month event</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdat our headquarters at the Evanston History Center in Evanston, Illinois. Author (and former NCWHS board member) Susan Ferentinos will speak about her recently published book,\ufffd\ufffd</span><em>Interpreting LGBT History at Museums and Historic Sites</em><span>, discussing the ways historians approach the study of same-sex relationships; the challenges to uncovering this past; and the efforts of museums, historic sites, and community groups to preserve this history and present it to the wider public. This program will be held on Thursday, March 26th at 7 pm (reception at 6:30) and is designed not only for those connected to a museum or site, but also for anyone who is concerned with issues of inclusion and diversity in our interpretation of the past. For more information about registering for this event, which is free to NCWHS members, visit our\ufffd\ufffd</span><a href="http://ncwhs.us6.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e1002e44a4679bee03c22e9a9&amp;id=702aa62a9c&amp;e=5452526ab2" target="_blank">website</a><span>.</span><br /><span>\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffdFinally, we know that word of mouth is our most important communication tool. Please\ufffd\ufffd</span><strong>forward this newsletter</strong><span>\ufffd\ufffdalong to anyone in your circle who would enjoy connecting with us. Building our network of members, supporters and friends is so important to us as an organization, and we know it is important to you, as we all work together to give women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history its place in American (and World) history.</span><br /><br /><strong>As always, stay in touch!</strong><br /><br /><span>Lori Osborne</span><br /><span>NCWHS Vice President</span></p></div></content>   <category term="Featured" />   <category term="News" />  </entry>  <entry>   <title>Interpreting LGBT History at Museums and Historic Sites </title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://ncwhs.org/index.php/136-news/271-interpret-lgbt-history"/>   <published>2015-02-25T20:44:13-05:00</published>   <updated>2015-02-25T20:44:13-05:00</updated>   <id>http://ncwhs.org/index.php/136-news/271-interpret-lgbt-history</id>   <author>    <name>Michael Regoli</name>    <email>ncwhs@regoli.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><strong>Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Month program at the Evanston History Center to focus on interpreting LGBT history at museums and historic sites</strong></p> <p>Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender (LGBT) individuals and families are increasingly visible in popular culture and local communities; their struggles for equality appear regularly in news media. While this is a relatively new situation, same-sex love and desire has a long-standing history and can provide historical context for current events.</p> <p><img src="images/stories/Ferentinos_Susan.png" border="0" width="125" height="143" style="float: right; margin: 5px; border: 1px solid black;" />Building from her recently published book, <a href="http://resource.aaslh.org/view/interpreting-lgbt-history-at-museums-and-historic-sites/"><em>Interpreting LGBT History at Museums and Historic Sites</em></a>, author Susan Ferentinos will discuss the ways historians approach the study of same-sex relationships; the challenges to uncovering this past; and the efforts of museums, historic sites, and community groups to preserve this history and present it to the wider public. Cosponsored by the <a href="http://evanstonwomen.org/">Evanston Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Project</a> and the National Collaborative for Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Sites (NCWHS), this program is designed not only for those connected to a museum or site, but also for anyone who is concerned with issues of inclusion and diversity in our interpretation of the past.</p> <p>Susan Ferentinos is a public history researcher, writer, and consultant based in Bloomington, Indiana, where she specializes in historical project management and the use of the past to create community. Dr. Ferentinos holds a Ph.D. in U.S. history with a focus on the history of gender and sexuality and a Master of Library Science with a concentration in special collections, both from Indiana University. She is also a former NCWHS board member. The talk will be held on <strong>Thursday, March 26, 2015</strong> at 7:00 p.m. Central (6:30 reception) at the Evanston History Center, 225 Greenwood Street, Evanston, Illinois. The cost is $10; free for NCWHS members. Reservations are encouraged. To make a reservation, please contact the Evanston History Center at (847) 475-3410 or email NCWHS at <a href="mailto:membership@ncwhs.org">membership@ncwhs.org</a>.</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><strong>Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Month program at the Evanston History Center to focus on interpreting LGBT history at museums and historic sites</strong></p> <p>Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender (LGBT) individuals and families are increasingly visible in popular culture and local communities; their struggles for equality appear regularly in news media. While this is a relatively new situation, same-sex love and desire has a long-standing history and can provide historical context for current events.</p> <p><img src="images/stories/Ferentinos_Susan.png" border="0" width="125" height="143" style="float: right; margin: 5px; border: 1px solid black;" />Building from her recently published book, <a href="http://resource.aaslh.org/view/interpreting-lgbt-history-at-museums-and-historic-sites/"><em>Interpreting LGBT History at Museums and Historic Sites</em></a>, author Susan Ferentinos will discuss the ways historians approach the study of same-sex relationships; the challenges to uncovering this past; and the efforts of museums, historic sites, and community groups to preserve this history and present it to the wider public. Cosponsored by the <a href="http://evanstonwomen.org/">Evanston Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Project</a> and the National Collaborative for Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Sites (NCWHS), this program is designed not only for those connected to a museum or site, but also for anyone who is concerned with issues of inclusion and diversity in our interpretation of the past.</p> <p>Susan Ferentinos is a public history researcher, writer, and consultant based in Bloomington, Indiana, where she specializes in historical project management and the use of the past to create community. Dr. Ferentinos holds a Ph.D. in U.S. history with a focus on the history of gender and sexuality and a Master of Library Science with a concentration in special collections, both from Indiana University. She is also a former NCWHS board member. The talk will be held on <strong>Thursday, March 26, 2015</strong> at 7:00 p.m. Central (6:30 reception) at the Evanston History Center, 225 Greenwood Street, Evanston, Illinois. The cost is $10; free for NCWHS members. Reservations are encouraged. To make a reservation, please contact the Evanston History Center at (847) 475-3410 or email NCWHS at <a href="mailto:membership@ncwhs.org">membership@ncwhs.org</a>.</p></div></content>   <category term="Featured" />   <category term="News" />  </entry>  <entry>   <title>In Memoriam: Dr. Jannelle Warren-Findley</title>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://ncwhs.org/index.php/136-news/270-in-memoriam-dr-jannelle-warren-findley"/>   <published>2015-02-13T14:01:11-05:00</published>   <updated>2015-02-13T14:01:11-05:00</updated>   <id>http://ncwhs.org/index.php/136-news/270-in-memoriam-dr-jannelle-warren-findley</id>   <author>    <name>Marla Miller</name>    <email>mmiller@history.umass.edu</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img src="http://publichistorycommons.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/warren-findley_jannelle_01.jpg" border="0" alt="Jann Warren-Findley" title="Jann Warren-Findley" width="186" height="276" style="float: right; margin: 20px;" />The public history community is mourning the passing of Dr. Jannelle Warren-Findley, who passed away on February 4, 2015, in Arizona.\ufffd\ufffd Jann was one of the founding directors of the National Collaborative for Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Sites in 2004 and served until 2007.\ufffd\ufffd During that time, she was a conference organizer for the West/Southwest Regional Meeting of the National Collaborative for Women's History Sites in 2004-2005.\ufffd\ufffd When Jann left the NCWHS board, she recommended that Mary Melcher replace her.</p> <p>Jann was an inspiration to many who work at the intersection of women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history and public history.\ufffd\ufffd One particularly memorable and powerful contribution was her work in organizing (with Mary Rothschild) the Second National Women in Historic Preservation Conference (1997), a watershed event for those of us interested in the documentation and interpretation of places associated with women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history. Many of us working in public history today found the series of conferences of which this was a part a turning point in our own careers, where scholarship was sharpened, networks thickened, and friendships forged.</p> <p>Jann served as president of the National Council on Public History and on the executive board of the Organization of American Historians, among many other professional activities. Her public history practice took her around the world, from New Zealand to China. \ufffd\ufffdShe retired from the Department of History at Arizona State University, where she taught public history, in 2014.</p> <p>Her obituary is available at <a href="http://www.tempemortuary.com/fh/obituaries/obituary.cfm?o_id=2952345&amp;fh_id=14347">http://www.tempemortuary.com/fh/obituaries/obituary.cfm?o_id=2952345&amp;fh_id=14347</a>.</p> <p>The National Council on Public History has a blog of memories about Jann at <a href="http://publichistorycommons.org/remembering-jann-warren-findley/">http://publichistorycommons.org/remembering-jann-warren-findley/</a></p> <p>\ufffd\ufffd</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img src="http://publichistorycommons.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/warren-findley_jannelle_01.jpg" border="0" alt="Jann Warren-Findley" title="Jann Warren-Findley" width="186" height="276" style="float: right; margin: 20px;" />The public history community is mourning the passing of Dr. Jannelle Warren-Findley, who passed away on February 4, 2015, in Arizona.\ufffd\ufffd Jann was one of the founding directors of the National Collaborative for Women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds History Sites in 2004 and served until 2007.\ufffd\ufffd During that time, she was a conference organizer for the West/Southwest Regional Meeting of the National Collaborative for Women's History Sites in 2004-2005.\ufffd\ufffd When Jann left the NCWHS board, she recommended that Mary Melcher replace her.</p> <p>Jann was an inspiration to many who work at the intersection of women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history and public history.\ufffd\ufffd One particularly memorable and powerful contribution was her work in organizing (with Mary Rothschild) the Second National Women in Historic Preservation Conference (1997), a watershed event for those of us interested in the documentation and interpretation of places associated with women\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds history. Many of us working in public history today found the series of conferences of which this was a part a turning point in our own careers, where scholarship was sharpened, networks thickened, and friendships forged.</p> <p>Jann served as president of the National Council on Public History and on the executive board of the Organization of American Historians, among many other professional activities. Her public history practice took her around the world, from New Zealand to China. \ufffd\ufffdShe retired from the Department of History at Arizona State University, where she taught public history, in 2014.</p> <p>Her obituary is available at <a href="http://www.tempemortuary.com/fh/obituaries/obituary.cfm?o_id=2952345&amp;fh_id=14347">http://www.tempemortuary.com/fh/obituaries/obituary.cfm?o_id=2952345&amp;fh_id=14347</a>.</p> <p>The National Council on Public History has a blog of memories about Jann at <a href="http://publichistorycommons.org/remembering-jann-warren-findley/">http://publichistorycommons.org/remembering-jann-warren-findley/</a></p> <p>\ufffd\ufffd</p></div></content>   <category term="Featured" />   <category term="News" />  </entry> </feed>
